sites.name: Guggenheim Museum Bilbao
sites.description: The Guggenheim Museum Bilbao is an iconic architectural masterpiece designed by Frank Gehry, completed in 1997. This titanium-clad structure with its undulating forms has become the symbol of Bilbao and sparked the city's urban renewal. Housing an impressive collection of modern and contemporary art, the museum features both permanent installations and rotating exhibitions. Outside, visitors encounter large-scale sculptures including Jeff Koons' floral 'Puppy' and Louise Bourgeois' spider 'Maman'.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with climate-controlled galleries. Less crowded on weekday mornings. Summer brings longer hours and increased visitors. Special exhibitions rotate seasonally. Museum exterior spectacularly illuminated at night. Annual events include Museum Night and International Museum Day with special programming.
sites.booking_tips: Online tickets recommended to avoid queues. Audio guides available in multiple languages. Guided tours offer deeper insights and require advance booking. Combined tickets with Fine Arts Museum available. Photography permitted in most galleries without flash.

sites.name: Casco Viejo (Old Town)
sites.description: Bilbao's Casco Viejo (Old Town) is the medieval heart of the city, featuring seven original streets ('Siete Calles') dating back to the 1400s. This pedestrian-friendly district houses historic landmarks including Santiago Cathedral, Plaza Nueva, and the Ribera Market. Narrow cobblestone streets are lined with pintxo bars, traditional shops, and boutiques. The neighborhood survived devastating floods in 1983 and has been beautifully restored, balancing historic character with contemporary Basque culture.
sites.seasonal_notes: Accessible year-round. Most vibrant during evening hours when locals engage in the pintxo crawl tradition. Special atmosphere during local festivals including Semana Grande (August) and Santo Tomás (December). Rain is common in Bilbao, but covered arcades in Plaza Nueva provide shelter. Summer evenings bring extended dining hours and street performances.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for district exploration. Guided walking tours recommended for historical context. Thursday evenings popular for pintxo crawls with locals. Combine with Ribera Market visit during morning hours. Accessible by metro and tram from other parts of Bilbao.

sites.name: Museo de Bellas Artes (Fine Arts Museum)
sites.description: The Bilbao Fine Arts Museum houses one of Spain's most important art collections outside Madrid, spanning from the 12th century to contemporary works. The museum combines two buildings—a 1945 classical structure and a modern 1970 addition—containing over 10,000 works. The collection features Spanish masters (El Greco, Goya, Zurbarán), Flemish paintings, and significant Basque artists alongside international works by Francis Bacon, Richard Serra, and others. The museum is celebrated for its balanced curation and visitor-friendly atmosphere.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with climate-controlled galleries. Free admission on Wednesdays. Exhibition schedule changes seasonally with special collections highlighted throughout the year. Less crowded than the Guggenheim, providing a more contemplative experience. The museum courtyard features rotating sculptural installations.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking typically necessary. Combined tickets with Guggenheim offer savings. Audio guides available in multiple languages. Located in Doña Casilda Park for combining cultural visit with green space. Restaurant on premises serves traditional Basque cuisine with seasonal menus.

sites.name: Mercado de la Ribera
sites.description: The Ribera Market is Europe's largest covered market by floor area, beautifully situated alongside the Nervión River. Renovated in 2012, this Art Deco building houses over 60 food stalls across three floors, showcasing the finest Basque ingredients including seafood, charcuterie, cheeses, produce, and wines. The ground floor houses a gastronomic space with pintxo bars and restaurants. Stained-glass windows and the riverfront location create a distinctive atmosphere for this culinary and cultural hub.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with stallholders operating morning to mid-afternoon. Closed Sundays except for restaurants. Busiest on Saturday mornings when locals shop for weekend meals. Seasonal Basque delicacies highlighted throughout the year. The market reflects the agricultural calendar with special emphasis on mushroom season (autumn) and seafood calendar.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for market exploration. Food tours available with advance reservation. Restaurant area remains open later than market stalls. Best visited midweek mornings for authentic local atmosphere and freshest selections. Combine with Old Town exploration for efficient sightseeing.

sites.name: Artxanda Funicular
sites.description: The Artxanda Funicular has connected downtown Bilbao to Mount Artxanda since 1915, providing a unique transportation experience and access to panoramic city views. The 3-minute journey climbs 226 meters over a track length of 770 meters. At the summit, a lookout terrace offers spectacular vistas of Bilbao nestled in its valley, surrounded by green mountains. The area features restaurants, walking paths, and recreational facilities including tennis courts and a small amusement park.
sites.seasonal_notes: Operates year-round with more frequent service in summer months. Sunset views particularly rewarding as city lights emerge. Clear winter days offer expansive visibility. Spring brings lush green surroundings. The mountaintop can be significantly cooler than the city, particularly in evening hours.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required. Return tickets provide savings. Bilbao Card includes free ride. Schedule varies by season with extended evening hours in summer. Worth combining with a meal at one of the scenic restaurants at the summit. Outdoor terraces subject to closure during inclement weather.

sites.name: Alhóndiga (Azkuna Zentroa)
sites.description: Azkuna Zentroa (formerly Alhóndiga) is a multidisciplinary cultural center housed in a former wine warehouse from 1909, reimagined by designer Philippe Starck in 2010. This striking space combines original industrial architecture with contemporary design elements including 43 unique columns supporting the atrium. The complex includes exhibition spaces, a cinema, library, gym, rooftop pool, restaurants, and shops. The center hosts regular cultural events, performances, and exhibitions representing Bilbao's commitment to urban regeneration.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with climate-controlled interior. Exhibition schedule changes seasonally. Rooftop pool operational during summer months (additional fee). Film festivals and cultural events throughout the year. The central atrium serves as community gathering space with changing decorative elements reflecting seasonal themes.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for general access. Exhibition spaces mostly free. Cinema tickets available online. Rooftop facilities require separate admission. Guided architectural tours available with advance reservation. Restaurant reservations recommended for dinner hours. Easily accessible from central Bilbao.

sites.name: San Mamés Stadium
sites.description: San Mamés Stadium, opened in 2013, is the home of Athletic Club Bilbao, one of Spain's most historic football clubs known for its policy of fielding only Basque players. This UEFA 5-star rated stadium seats 53,000 spectators and features an innovative design with an exterior façade of 2,671 LED-illuminated ETFE panels that can change color. The stadium is named after its predecessor and integrated into the urban fabric, exemplifying contemporary sports architecture while honoring club traditions dating back to 1898.
sites.seasonal_notes: Stadium tours operate year-round. Match day experiences available during La Liga season (August to May). Museum open daily with extended hours on match days. Special illumination of exterior during evening games and significant events. The stadium environment most vibrant on match days when local supporters gather in surrounding bars.
sites.booking_tips: Stadium tour tickets available online with time slots. Match tickets should be purchased well in advance through official channels. Museum can be visited separately from tours. Combined tickets offer savings. Athletic Club membership provides priority access. Located near San Mamés metro station for convenient access.

sites.name: Vizcaya Bridge (Puente Bizkaia)
sites.description: The Vizcaya Bridge (Puente Bizkaia) is the world's oldest transporter bridge, connecting Portugalete and Getxo across the Nervión River. Built in 1893 and designed by Alberto Palacio (a student of Gustave Eiffel), this UNESCO World Heritage site combines iron architecture with innovative engineering. The gondola transports vehicles and pedestrians between banks in 90 seconds, while a high walkway offers pedestrian crossing and panoramic views. The bridge represents the industrial revolution's impact on northern Spain.
sites.seasonal_notes: Bridge operates year-round with reduced hours during holidays. Gondola service runs continuously throughout the day. Upper walkway may close during high winds or inclement weather. Summer brings busier crossings with tourists. The structure illuminated at night creates dramatic photo opportunities. Heritage Day (September) features special events celebrating the bridge's history.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for gondola crossing. Tickets for upper walkway available at control booths. Combination tickets include both services. Accessible by metro from central Bilbao. Worth combining with exploration of historic Portugalete and upscale Getxo areas connected by the bridge. Maritime Museum nearby provides historical context.

sites.name: Doña Casilda Park
sites.description: Doña Casilda Park (Parque de Doña Casilda de Iturrizar) is Bilbao's central urban park, designed in the English romantic style and opened in 1907. This 8.5-hectare green space features formal gardens, a large pond with waterfowl, tree-lined promenades, and sculptures. The park houses the Bilbao Fine Arts Museum along its perimeter. A central gathering place for locals, the park offers a peaceful respite from urban life while showcasing seasonal plantings and century-old specimens of trees from around the world.
sites.seasonal_notes: Accessible year-round from sunrise to sunset. Spring brings flowering bulbs and cherry blossoms. Summer features outdoor concerts and cultural events. Autumn creates colorful foliage displays from diverse tree collection. Duck pond popular with families throughout the year. Scheduled botanical guided tours during growing season.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Free concerts and events during summer months. Dance pavilion hosts weekend traditional dance sessions. Water features operate during daylight hours. Conveniently located between Guggenheim and Fine Arts museums for a cultural itinerary with green space breaks. Multiple cafes along perimeter offer refreshments.

sites.name: Euskal Museoa (Basque Museum)
sites.description: The Basque Museum in Bilbao provides a comprehensive introduction to Basque culture, history, and traditions. Housed in a former Jesuit cloister and church from the 17th century, the museum's collection spans archaeology, ethnography, maritime history, and folk traditions. Exhibits include traditional Basque sports equipment, fishing gear, agricultural implements, and reconstructions of rural Basque architecture. The museum serves as an important center for preservation and research of Basque cultural heritage.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with climate-controlled galleries. Special exhibitions highlighting different aspects of Basque culture rotate seasonally. Traditional craft demonstrations scheduled throughout the year. Basque language workshops offered periodically. Less crowded on weekday mornings. Local festivities celebrated with special programming.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required. Free admission on Thursdays. Guided tours in multiple languages available with reservation. Located in the Old Town for combined sightseeing. Audio guides provide detailed context for ethnographic displays. Interactive exhibits particularly engaging for younger visitors.

sites.name: Arriaga Theater
sites.description: The Arriaga Theater is a neo-baroque architectural gem inaugurated in 1890 and named after Juan Crisóstomo Arriaga, the 'Spanish Mozart.' After suffering fire and flood damage throughout its history, the theater was meticulously restored to its original splendor. The ornate façade and luxurious interior feature elaborate decorations, a grand staircase, and exceptional acoustics. As one of Bilbao's premier cultural venues, it hosts opera, theater, dance performances, and concerts representing both classical and contemporary productions.
sites.seasonal_notes: Performance season runs September through June with varying schedule. Summer months feature limited programming. Historical guided tours available when performances not in session. Christmas season brings special holiday performances. Annual opera festival in February-March attracts international talent. Lobby exhibitions rotate throughout the year.
sites.booking_tips: Performance tickets available online, best secured weeks in advance. Building tours require separate booking through tourist office. Evening performances typically begin at 8:00 PM. Dress code relatively casual but elegant attire common for premieres. Located at the edge of Old Town and easily accessible by tram. Theater café offers pre-show dining options.

sites.name: Maritime Museum Bilbao
sites.description: The Maritime Museum Bilbao celebrates the city's deep connection to seafaring and shipbuilding. Located in former dry docks where ships were once constructed, the museum combines outdoor displays including actual vessels with indoor exhibitions on naval architecture, fishing traditions, port history, and maritime commerce. The museum documents how the Nervión River shaped Bilbao's development from medieval trading port to industrial powerhouse. Interactive displays explain shipbuilding techniques and navigation technologies throughout history.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with both indoor and outdoor exhibits. Indoor galleries provide climate-controlled environment. Outdoor vessel displays best viewed in fair weather. Special exhibitions rotate seasonally. Harbor Day celebrations in July feature demonstrations and expanded programming. Winter months bring focus on maritime education activities.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking typically required. Free admission first Sunday of each month. Guided tours available with reservation. Located near Guggenheim for convenient cultural itinerary. Model ship building demonstrations scheduled regularly. Combined tickets with other maritime attractions available through tourist office.

sites.name: Plaza Nueva
sites.description: Plaza Nueva (New Square) is Bilbao's most elegant public space, a neoclassical square completed in 1851 after nearly 50 years of construction. The symmetrical design features arcaded walkways surrounding all four sides, providing shelter during Bilbao's frequent rain showers. The square hosts the Sunday market where antiques, books, coins, and other collectibles are traded. Surrounding pintxo bars and cafes create a lively atmosphere, particularly on weekends when local families gather and children play in the central space.
sites.seasonal_notes: Accessible year-round. Sunday market operates weekly regardless of weather (8:00 AM to 2:00 PM). Summer evenings bring outdoor dining under the arcades. Special festivals including Santo Tomás market (December 21) feature traditional Basque products. The enclosed design provides comfortable gathering space even during inclement weather.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for general access. Guided Old Town tours typically include the square. Restaurants surrounding the plaza require reservations for dinner, especially weekends. Traditional pintxo bars under arcades operate first-come basis. Thursday evenings popular for pintxo crawls with locals. Municipal tourist office located nearby for information.

sites.name: Bilbao Cathedral (Catedral de Santiago)
sites.description: Bilbao Cathedral, dedicated to St. James (Santiago), is the city's oldest religious building, with origins dating to the 14th-15th centuries. This Gothic basilica features a striking façade, soaring naves, and an elegantly vaulted cloister. The cathedral houses notable religious artwork, ornate chapels, and an impressive pipe organ. As a key stop on the northern route of the Camino de Santiago pilgrimage, the cathedral maintains spiritual significance while representing the religious heritage of the Basque region.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with reduced hours during religious services. Holy Week (Easter) brings special ceremonies and processions. Christmas season features traditional Basque nativity displays. Summer months offer extended visiting hours. Feast of St. James (July 25) celebrated with special liturgies. Organ concerts scheduled periodically throughout the year.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for general access. Religious services may restrict tourist visits. Small donation requested for cloister access. Guided tours available through diocese with advance reservation. Located in Old Town for combined sightseeing. Modest dress appropriate for church visit. Photography permitted without flash.

sites.name: Getxo
sites.description: Getxo is an upscale coastal suburb of Bilbao featuring historic mansions, sandy beaches, and a picturesque marina. This area developed in the late 19th century as wealthy industrialists built elaborate summer residences, creating the distinctive Algorta and Neguri neighborhoods with their Anglo-inspired architecture. The waterfront promenade stretches along dramatic cliffs and beaches, offering Atlantic views. The old fishing port of Algorta provides a contrasting traditional atmosphere with narrow streets and seafood taverns.
sites.seasonal_notes: Accessible year-round. Summer brings beach activities and sailing from the marina. Autumn and winter create dramatic seascapes during Atlantic storms. The clifftop walks most pleasant on clear days. Beaches receive Blue Flag certification annually. Music festivals and outdoor markets scheduled during summer months. Old Port area consistently lively regardless of season.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for district exploration. Easily reached by metro from central Bilbao. Vizcaya Bridge provides historic connection to Portugalete area. Boat tours of the coastline available from marina with advance booking. Cycling path connects entire coastline for active exploration. Seafood restaurants require reservations during summer season and weekends.

sites.name: Gexto Aquarium
sites.description: The Getxo Aquarium showcases the marine biodiversity of the Bay of Biscay and global ocean ecosystems. Located near Getxo's marina, the facility houses over 200 species in themed exhibits representing different marine environments. The centerpiece is the Cantabrian Sea tunnel where visitors experience sharks, rays, and other large species swimming overhead. Interactive touch pools, conservation exhibits, and educational displays about sustainable fishing practices and marine protection complement the living collections.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with climate-controlled environment. Less crowded on weekday mornings. Special holiday programming during school breaks. Feeding demonstrations scheduled throughout the day. Summer features extended evening hours and additional educational activities. Conservation-themed exhibitions rotate seasonally highlighting regional marine issues.
sites.booking_tips: Online tickets recommended during peak season. Combined tickets with boat tours available. Feeding times posted at entrance and online. Family tickets offer savings. Located in Getxo, accessible by metro from Bilbao. Adjacent restaurant specializes in sustainable seafood. Educational workshops for children require separate registration.

sites.name: Bilbao La Vieja (Art District)
sites.description: Bilbao La Vieja, once the medieval mining district and later a neglected area, has transformed into the city's creative and multicultural hub. Across the river from the Old Town, this neighborhood now houses art galleries, design studios, alternative music venues, and innovative gastronomy. Street art and murals adorn previously abandoned buildings. The area maintains its authentic character while welcoming artists, entrepreneurs, and visitors seeking Bilbao's contemporary cultural expression beyond the established museums.
sites.seasonal_notes: District accessible year-round. Gallery openings typically held on Thursday evenings. Street art best viewed during daylight hours. Summer brings outdoor events and pop-up markets. Cultural associations organize seasonal festivals highlighting neighborhood diversity. Weekend nights feature alternative music scene. First Saturday monthly market showcases local designers and artisans.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for district exploration. Guided street art tours available through local cultural associations. Gallery exhibitions free to access. Located across the river from Old Town via San Antón Bridge. Some areas still transitioning, best visited during daylight or early evening. Combines well with riverfront walk along the revitalized industrial areas.

sites.name: Funicular de Artxanda
sites.description: The Artxanda Funicular has connected downtown Bilbao to Mount Artxanda since 1915, providing a unique transportation experience and access to panoramic city views. The 3-minute journey climbs 226 meters over a track length of 770 meters. At the summit, a lookout terrace offers spectacular vistas of Bilbao nestled in its valley, surrounded by green mountains. The area features restaurants, walking paths, and recreational facilities including tennis courts and a small amusement park.
sites.seasonal_notes: Operates year-round with more frequent service in summer months. Sunset views particularly rewarding as city lights emerge. Clear winter days offer expansive visibility. Spring brings lush green surroundings. The mountaintop can be significantly cooler than the city, particularly in evening hours.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required. Return tickets provide savings. Bilbao Card includes free ride. Schedule varies by season with extended evening hours in summer. Worth combining with a meal at one of the scenic restaurants at the summit. Outdoor terraces subject to closure during inclement weather.

sites.name: Bilbao Art District
sites.description: Bilbao Art District encompasses the creative zone clustered around the Guggenheim Museum and extending into surrounding neighborhoods. This area features contemporary art galleries, design shops, creative studios, and cultural spaces that have emerged following the city's artistic renaissance. First Thursday evenings each month bring coordinated gallery openings and extended hours. The district represents Bilbao's evolution from industrial center to cultural destination, with both established institutions and independent spaces contributing to the dynamic arts scene.
sites.seasonal_notes: Galleries operate year-round with individual hours. First Thursday monthly events most vibrant for art exploration. Summer brings outdoor installations and performances. Annual Bilbao Art Week (October) features special exhibitions and events across the district. Winter focus shifts to indoor gallery programs with opening receptions offering opportunity to meet artists.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for gallery visits. Art District map available from tourist offices and participating galleries. First Thursday guided routes available with advance reservation. Most galleries closed Mondays. Combines well with Guggenheim visit. Many venues offer free exhibition catalogs and artist information. Contemporary art purchases available directly from galleries.

sites.name: Mirador de Artxanda
sites.description: The Artxanda Lookout provides the definitive panoramic view of Bilbao from a mountain terrace accessible via the historic funicular railway. This elevated vantage point offers a complete perspective of the city nestled in its valley, with the Nervión River winding through the urban landscape. Information panels identify key landmarks. Beyond the immediate viewing platform, Mount Artxanda offers walking trails through woodland areas, recreational facilities, and several restaurants serving traditional Basque cuisine with spectacular views.
sites.seasonal_notes: Lookout accessible year-round though visibility varies with weather conditions. Evening views showcase city illumination. Morning visits offer photographic opportunities with optimal natural light. Sunset particularly dramatic as golden light bathes the city. Mountaintop significantly cooler than city center, especially in evening hours.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for lookout access. Funicular ticket separate expense. Restaurants on mountaintop require reservations, especially for sunset dining. Photography enthusiasts should bring zoom lenses for detailed cityscape shots. Walking paths beyond lookout offer additional perspectives. Taxis available for return journey if funicular closed.

neighborhoods.name: Casco Viejo
neighborhoods.character: Bilbao's medieval heart with narrow cobblestone streets, historic buildings, and dense concentration of pintxo bars and traditional shops.

location.description: Located on the eastern bank of the Nervión River, it's the original nucleus of Bilbao founded in 1300.

history.overview: The original medieval settlement of Bilbao founded in 1300, built around seven parallel streets that still form its core today.
history.significance: Represents the historical origins of Bilbao and survived both wars and devastating floods to remain the cultural heart of the city.
notable_events: Construction of Santiago Cathedral starting in the 14th century
Devastating floods in 1983 that damaged much of the district
Comprehensive restoration and pedestrianization in the 1990s

transit: Tram stops at Ribera and Arriaga
Multiple bus lines at the perimeter
practical_info.safety: Very safe during day and evening; be aware of pickpockets during busy hours.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Early evenings for the authentic pintxo experience; Sunday mornings for the traditional market.
practical_info.walkability: Highly walkable pedestrianized zone with limited vehicle access.

attractions.name: Plaza Nueva
attractions.description: Neoclassical square completed in 1851 surrounded by arcaded walkways housing traditional bars and restaurants.
attractions.appeal: Experience Bilbao's social heart where locals gather for pintxos, especially during Sunday markets and festivals.

attractions.name: Santiago Cathedral
attractions.description: Gothic cathedral dating from the 14th-15th centuries dedicated to Bilbao's patron saint with impressive vaulted interior.
attractions.appeal: Explore Bilbao's most important religious building and a key stop on the northern route of the Camino de Santiago pilgrimage.

attractions.name: Mercado de la Ribera
attractions.description: Europe's largest covered market renovated in Art Deco style, featuring fresh local produce and a vibrant food hall.
attractions.appeal: Shop alongside locals for the finest Basque ingredients or enjoy pintxos with river views at the ground floor gastro space.

dining.name: Gure Toki
dining.known_for: Award-winning creative pintxos that blend tradition with innovation
dining.atmosphere: Contemporary bar in Plaza Nueva with outdoor seating and lively ambiance.

dining.name: Bar Zuga
dining.known_for: Classic Basque pintxos perfected over decades
dining.atmosphere: Authentic old-school tavern buzzing with locals and visitors alike.

dining.name: Baster
dining.known_for: Contemporary take on traditional flavors with visual flair
dining.atmosphere: Stylish yet casual space perfect for sampling innovative small plates.

activities.name: Pintxo Crawl
activities.description: Self-guided or organized tour of the old town's best pintxo bars sampling unique specialties at each stop.

activities.name: Seven Streets Tour
activities.description: Guided walking tour exploring the original seven medieval streets that formed Bilbao's first urban layout.

stay_here_if: You want to be immersed in traditional Basque culture and cuisine.
You prefer historic surroundings and authentic atmosphere.
You want to be within walking distance of major cultural sites.
avoid_if: You're sensitive to noise (can be lively at night, especially weekends).
You need modern amenities and spacious accommodations.
You prefer proximity to contemporary attractions like the Guggenheim.
insider_tips: Thursday evening is 'pintxo-pote' night when many bars offer special prices for a pintxo and drink.
Visit Mercado de la Ribera in the morning to see the best fish selection and local shopping activity.
The Sunday antique market in Plaza Nueva offers unique souvenirs and local atmosphere.

neighborhoods.name: Abando
neighborhoods.character: Bilbao's elegant 19th-century expansion district featuring grand boulevards, upscale shopping, financial institutions, and the city's main cultural venues.

location.description: Located on the west bank of the Nervión River, developed as Bilbao's 19th-century expansion when it became an industrial powerhouse.

history.overview: Developed in the late 19th century as Bilbao's industrial wealth grew, designed as a grid-patterned expansion of the medieval city.
history.significance: Represents Bilbao's industrial golden age and transformation into a financial center with impressive architecture.
notable_events: 1876 city expansion plan following the grid pattern of Barcelona's Eixample
Construction of Grand Buildings during mining and industrial boom (1880-1910)
Development as financial district in the 20th century
Urban renewal in the late 20th century preserving historic architecture

transit: Metro lines 1 and 2 at Abando and Moyua stations
practical_info.safety: Very safe area with good lighting and police presence.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Weekdays for shopping and business atmosphere; weekends for a more relaxed experience.
practical_info.walkability: Excellent walkability with wide sidewalks and pedestrian-friendly areas.

attractions.name: Plaza Moyua
attractions.description: Elegant circular plaza with gardens and the historic Carlton Hotel, forming the heart of the Ensanche district.
attractions.appeal: Experience the geometric center of Bilbao's planned expansion with its impressive fountain and surrounding Belle Époque buildings.

attractions.name: Gran Vía Don Diego López de Haro
attractions.description: Bilbao's main commercial avenue lined with impressive buildings, department stores, and international brands.
attractions.appeal: Shop at upscale stores or simply admire the architectural harmony of this boulevard modeled after major European cities.

attractions.name: Doña Casilda Park
attractions.description: Romantic English-style park featuring a pond, sculptures, and tree-lined promenades adjacent to the Fine Arts Museum.
attractions.appeal: Enjoy a peaceful green respite from urban explorations with classical landscaping and frequent outdoor events.

dining.name: La Viña del Ensanche
dining.known_for: Premium Iberian ham, classic pintxos, and extensive Spanish wine selection
dining.atmosphere: Historic tavern with marble bar, hanging hams, and elegant clientele.

dining.name: Zortziko
dining.known_for: Michelin-starred Basque cuisine in a belle époque setting
dining.atmosphere: Elegant dining room with classical décor and refined service.

dining.name: El Globo
dining.known_for: Historic café serving churros with chocolate and classic pastries
dining.atmosphere: Time-honored café with Art Deco elements frequented by locals of all generations.

activities.name: Architectural Walking Tour
activities.description: Guided or self-guided tour of the Ensanche's impressive buildings showcasing styles from Belle Époque to Art Deco.

activities.name: Shopping Experience
activities.description: Explore Gran Vía and surrounding streets featuring international brands, local boutiques, and department stores.

stay_here_if: You want central accommodation with good transit connections.
You're interested in upscale shopping and dining.
You prefer elegant surroundings with good amenities.
avoid_if: You're seeking authentic old-world charm and medieval streets.
You want to avoid business district prices and formality.
You prefer a more local, less commercial neighborhood experience.
insider_tips: Visit Doña Casilda Park early morning to see locals practicing tai chi and traditional dance.
The top floor of El Corte Inglés department store offers excellent city views and a good-value café.
Many banks and institutions in Abando feature impressive lobby architecture that can be visited during business hours.

neighborhoods.name: Abandoibarra
neighborhoods.character: Bilbao's showcase regeneration zone transformed from industrial riverfront to cultural powerhouse featuring iconic architecture and public art.

location.description: Located along the west bank of the Nervión River between Abando and Deusto, completely reimagined from former shipyards and docks.

history.overview: Former industrial riverfront with shipyards and docks that was completely transformed beginning in the 1990s as part of Bilbao's urban renaissance.
history.significance: Symbolizes Bilbao's transformation from industrial decline to cultural and architectural showcase.
notable_events: Industrial activity along the riverfront through most of the 20th century
Economic crisis and deindustrialization in the 1980s
Opening of the Guggenheim Museum in 1997 catalyzing the area's rebirth
Ongoing development with parks, cultural venues, and architectural landmarks

transit: Metro lines 1 and 2 at Moyua station (short walk)
practical_info.safety: Extremely safe area with excellent lighting and security presence.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Morning for museum visits; sunset for dramatic light on the Guggenheim's titanium panels.
practical_info.walkability: Outstanding riverside promenade connecting attractions with scenic views.

attractions.name: Guggenheim Museum Bilbao
attractions.description: Frank Gehry's titanium-clad masterpiece housing contemporary art collections and large-scale installations.
attractions.appeal: Experience the building that transformed Bilbao's global image, featuring works by major contemporary artists and the museum that sparked the term 'the Bilbao Effect.'

attractions.name: Euskalduna Palace
attractions.description: Striking performance venue designed to resemble a ship under construction, referencing the site's shipbuilding past.
attractions.appeal: Attend world-class performances in one of Spain's leading concert halls or simply admire its innovative architecture symbolizing Bilbao's transformation.

attractions.name: Abandoibarra Riverfront Walk
attractions.description: Landscaped riverside walk featuring public art installations, gardens, and views of Bilbao's architectural landmarks.
attractions.appeal: Stroll along the beautifully redesigned riverfront to experience Bilbao's renaissance, featuring works by artists like Daniel Buren, Jeff Koons, and Louise Bourgeois.

dining.name: Bistró Guggenheim
dining.known_for: Contemporary menu in remarkable museum setting
dining.atmosphere: Elegant dining space with museum views and artistic ambiance.

dining.name: Nerua
dining.known_for: Michelin-starred minimalist cuisine focusing on pure flavors
dining.atmosphere: Sophisticated museum restaurant with understated design emphasizing the dining experience.

dining.name: Azurmendi Prêt À Porter
dining.known_for: Accessible offerings from three-Michelin-starred chef Eneko Atxa
dining.atmosphere: Contemporary casual dining space within the striking architecture of Euskalduna Palace.

activities.name: Architectural Photography Tour
activities.description: Self-guided or organized tour capturing Abandoibarra's architectural landmarks in different lights.

activities.name: Public Art Walk
activities.description: Stroll along the riverside to view major public artworks including 'Puppy' by Jeff Koons and 'Maman' by Louise Bourgeois.

stay_here_if: You want to be close to Bilbao's most iconic attractions.
You're a fan of contemporary architecture and design.
You prefer modern accommodations with riverside views.
avoid_if: You're seeking authentic local neighborhoods over tourist areas.
You prefer historic buildings and traditional character.
You're on a tight budget (accommodation tends to be expensive).
insider_tips: Visit the Guggenheim in late afternoon to see how the titanium panels change color with the setting sun.
The best photos of the museum can be taken from across the river in Deusto, especially at sunset.
Many of the area's best architectural views are free, including the riverside walk and exterior sculptures.

neighborhoods.name: Bilbao La Vieja
neighborhoods.character: Former working-class neighborhood turned creative hub featuring street art, alternative culture, international influences, and emerging art scene.

location.description: Located across the river from the Casco Viejo, one of Bilbao's oldest districts now experiencing creative regeneration.

history.overview: Originally developed in the medieval period outside the city walls, became a mining and working-class district before experiencing decline and recent creative resurgence.
history.significance: Represents Bilbao's edgier side and ongoing grassroots regeneration through arts and culture rather than top-down planning.
notable_events: Medieval development as area outside city walls
19th century mining and industrial worker housing
Period of decline and marginalization in late 20th century
Artist-led revival beginning in early 2000s with continuing transformation

transit: Casco Viejo metro station (across the river)
practical_info.safety: Improving but still transitional; safe during day and evening hours in main areas.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Afternoon and early evening when galleries and creative spaces are open.
practical_info.walkability: Very walkable though some streets have steep inclines.

attractions.name: BilboRock
attractions.description: Former church converted into alternative cultural venue hosting concerts, exhibitions, and creative events.
attractions.appeal: Experience Bilbao's alternative cultural scene in a repurposed religious building symbolizing the area's transformation.

attractions.name: Street Art Route
attractions.description: Self-guided tour of large-scale murals and street art pieces throughout the district's buildings and walls.
attractions.appeal: Discover how public art has helped transform the neighborhood while expressing social and cultural themes relevant to Bilbao.

attractions.name: La Merced Market
attractions.description: Former market building now hosting creative businesses, workshops, and cultural events.
attractions.appeal: Visit a center of the neighborhood's creative economy where traditional architecture meets contemporary use.

dining.name: Marzana 16
dining.known_for: Creative cuisine blending Basque tradition with global influences
dining.atmosphere: Industrial-chic space with artistic touches and casual vibe.

dining.name: El Perro Chico
dining.atmosphere: Cozy tavern bridging traditional and modern in a historic building.

dining.name: Mugi
dining.known_for: Globally-inspired casual fare with vegetarian options
dining.atmosphere: Relaxed café with community focus and artistic clientele.

activities.name: Gallery Hopping
activities.description: Visit independent galleries and artist studios showcasing emerging talent and contemporary works.

activities.name: Alternative Bilbao Tour
activities.description: Guided exploration of the district's transformation, street art, and creative initiatives.

stay_here_if: You seek authentic, non-touristy neighborhoods with creative energy.
You're comfortable in urban areas in transition.
You want budget-friendly accommodation with character.
avoid_if: You're uncomfortable in neighborhoods still in transition.
You want conventional tourist experiences and attractions.
insider_tips: First Friday monthly gallery nights bring openings and events across multiple venues.
Some of the best views of the Old Town can be captured from the hillside streets of this district.
Small creative shops offer unique, locally-made souvenirs at better prices than tourist areas.

fine_dining.name: Azurmendi
signature_dishes: Truffled Egg Yolk with Carbonated Herb Consommé
Roasted Lobster with Wild Herb Infusion
fine_dining.atmosphere: Stunning eco-sustainable glass pavilion surrounded by countryside with gardens and greenhouse
fine_dining.booking_tips: Book 2-3 months in advance, especially for weekend dining
fine_dining.local_tips: Chef Eneko Atxa's dining experience begins with a tour through different spaces; request the kitchen tour option

fine_dining.name: Nerua
signature_dishes: Garden of Vegetables with Local Herbs
fine_dining.atmosphere: Minimalist, elegant dining room within the Guggenheim Museum with views of the Nervión River
fine_dining.booking_tips: Reserve at least 1 month in advance, closed Monday and Sunday evening
fine_dining.local_tips: Chef Josean Alija focuses on purity of flavors; their seasonally changing tasting menu offers the best experience

fine_dining.name: Etxanobe Atelier
signature_dishes: Sea Urchin with Cauliflower and Truffle
fine_dining.atmosphere: Sophisticated dining space with contemporary art and open kitchen
fine_dining.booking_tips: Book 3-4 weeks in advance, closed Sunday and Monday
fine_dining.local_tips: Chef Fernando Canales combines traditional Basque ingredients with modern techniques; their cheese selection is outstanding

fine_dining.name: Mina
fine_dining.atmosphere: Intimate, converted warehouse with industrial elements and open kitchen counter seating
fine_dining.booking_tips: Reserve 3-4 weeks ahead, request counter seats for kitchen views
fine_dining.local_tips: Chefs Álvaro Garrido and Lara Martín offer creative tasting menus that change constantly; wine pairings showcase small Spanish producers

fine_dining.name: Zortziko
signature_dishes: Hake with Kokotxas in Green Sauce
fine_dining.atmosphere: Elegant belle époque dining room in a historic building with classical décor
fine_dining.booking_tips: Book 2 weeks ahead, closed Sunday evening and Monday
fine_dining.local_tips: Chef Daniel García is a master of traditional Basque haute cuisine; excellent for business dinners with the menu ejecutivo

casual_dining.name: La Viña del Ensanche
casual_dining.atmosphere: Classic Basque tavern with marble bar, hanging hams, and lively ambiance
casual_dining.booking_tips: Book for sit-down meals; bar area accepts walk-ins for pintxos
casual_dining.local_tips: Over 100 years old; famous for their hand-carved jamón and extensive Spanish wine selection

casual_dining.name: Gure Toki
signature_dishes: Foie with Apple and Pedro Ximénez Reduction
casual_dining.atmosphere: Contemporary tavern in historic square with outdoor seating
casual_dining.booking_tips: No reservations for bar; arrive early evenings to avoid crowds
casual_dining.local_tips: Award-winning creative pintxos; order hot pintxos from the menu rather than just selecting from the bar

casual_dining.name: Bascook
signature_dishes: Octopus with Sweet Potato and Kimchi
casual_dining.atmosphere: Industrial-chic restaurant in former warehouse with contemporary design
casual_dining.booking_tips: Book several days ahead, especially for weekends
casual_dining.local_tips: Chef Aitor Elizegi creates globally-influenced Basque cuisine; daily menú del día offers excellent value for high-quality cooking

casual_dining.name: El Perro Chico
signature_dishes: Slow-cooked Egg with Mushrooms and Truffle
Bacalao al Pilpil (Cod in Garlic-Olive Oil Emulsion)
casual_dining.atmosphere: Cozy tavern with rustic-modern décor in historic building
casual_dining.booking_tips: Book for lunch; dinner usually accommodates walk-ins
casual_dining.local_tips: Named after the historic narrow street it's located on; good mix of traditional and modern Basque cuisine

casual_dining.name: Momatxo
casual_dining.atmosphere: Bright, modern bistro with open kitchen and minimalist design
casual_dining.local_tips: Off the tourist path with fantastic daily market menu based on what was fresh that morning

casual_dining.name: Zarate
casual_dining.atmosphere: Modern, understated dining room with focus on the food
casual_dining.booking_tips: Reserve for weekend lunches at least a week ahead
casual_dining.local_tips: Chef Sergio Ortiz de Zarate is a master with seafood; fish is cooked in front of diners on a wood-fired grill

casual_dining.name: Bistró Guggenheim
casual_dining.atmosphere: Sleek, design-forward space within the iconic museum
casual_dining.booking_tips: Reserve for lunch after museum visit; special entry package available
casual_dining.local_tips: More casual alternative to Nerua in the same building; perfect for lunch after visiting the museum

street_food.name: Mercado de la Ribera Pintxo Bars
street_food.local_tips: Europe's largest covered market houses several pintxo bars; try traditional Gildas, named after Rita Hayworth's character

street_food.name: Casco Viejo Pintxo Crawl
street_food.local_tips: Thursday evening is 'pintxo-pote' night when many bars offer a pintxo and drink at reduced prices

street_food.name: El Globo
street_food.local_tips: Historic churro establishment; locals come after dinner for late-night churros con chocolate

street_food.name: Café Iruña
street_food.local_tips: Historic café with Moorish-influenced décor; their bocadillo de tortilla (Spanish omelette sandwich) is perfect for a quick lunch

street_food.name: La Campa de los Ingleses Market
street_food.local_tips: Rotating weekend food market with varied international options; great riverside setting next to the Guggenheim

coffee_shops.name: La Marzocco Café
coffee_shops.atmosphere: Contemporary, minimalist café with focus on coffee quality
coffee_shops.food_options: Artisanal pastries and light breakfast items
coffee_shops.local_tips: The pioneer of specialty coffee in Bilbao; baristas compete internationally

coffee_shops.name: Bihotz Café
coffee_shops.atmosphere: Rustic-industrial space with vintage elements and local art
coffee_shops.local_tips: Transforms from café to craft beer bar in the evening; hosts coffee cupping sessions monthly

coffee_shops.name: Mami Lou
coffee_shops.atmosphere: Cozy, French-inspired café with vintage furnishings
coffee_shops.food_options: Full breakfast menu and French pastries
coffee_shops.local_tips: All pastries made in-house; great for traditional European breakfast

coffee_shops.name: El Cafetín
coffee_shops.atmosphere: Classic Spanish café with traditional décor and local clientele
coffee_shops.local_tips: Where locals start their day; excellent traditional breakfast with tomato toast and olive oil

coffee_shops.name: Cafetería Sainz
coffee_shops.atmosphere: Traditional Bilbao café with marble tables and classic ambiance
coffee_shops.food_options: Full selection of traditional Basque pastries
coffee_shops.local_tips: Family-owned since 1962; famous for traditional Bilbao pastries like Carolinas and Rusos

bars.name: El Txikito
bars.atmosphere: Classic Basque tavern with long bar filled with pintxos and lively ambiance
bars.local_tips: Watch the theatrical pouring of txakoli wine from height to create aeration; pair with anchovies

bars.name: La Viña del Ensanche
bars.atmosphere: Classic tavern with walls lined with bottles and hanging hams
bars.food_options: Premium ibérico ham and aged cheeses
bars.local_tips: Over 200 Spanish wines available; the house vermouth on tap is exceptional

bars.name: Singular
signature_drinks: Bilbao Sour (Patxaran-based twist on whiskey sour)
bars.atmosphere: Sophisticated cocktail bar with art deco elements and intimate lighting
bars.local_tips: The mixologists create Basque-inspired cocktails using local ingredients like patxaran (sloe liqueur)

bars.name: Residence
bars.atmosphere: Modern rooftop terrace with panoramic city views
bars.local_tips: The best sunset views in Bilbao; each gin & tonic is served with specific botanicals and premium tonics

bars.name: Pub Lamiak
bars.atmosphere: Laid-back beer bar with rustic elements and friendly ambiance
bars.local_tips: Named after mythological Basque creatures; offers the best selection of local craft beers in Bilbao

bars.name: Café Iruña
bars.atmosphere: Stunning Moorish-inspired historic café with ornate tiles and vintage charm
bars.local_tips: Operating since 1903 with largely unchanged décor; the afternoon vermouth hour is a Bilbao tradition

food_tours.name: Pintxos Crawl in Casco Viejo
highlights: Guided tour of Old Town's best pintxo bars
Introduction to txakoli wine and cider pouring
food_tours.booking_tips: Book at least a week in advance; tours explain the culture and etiquette of pintxo dining

food_tours.name: Mercado de la Ribera Gastro Tour
highlights: Guided tour of Europe's largest covered market
Tasting of Basque cheeses, charcuterie, and wines
food_tours.booking_tips: Morning tours recommended when market is most active; comfortable shoes suggested

food_tours.name: Rioja Alavesa Wine Region Day Trip
highlights: Visits to traditional and modern wineries
Traditional Riojan lunch at a bodega
food_tours.booking_tips: Book 10-14 days ahead; includes transportation from Bilbao to nearby wine region

food_tours.name: Basque Cider House Experience
highlights: Traditional cider house menu with cider poured from large barrels
food_tours.booking_tips: Seasonal (January-April is traditional cider season); includes transportation to nearby cider region

cooking_classes.name: Basque Pintxos Workshop
includes: All ingredients, recipes, pintxo lunch with wine
cooking_classes.booking_tips: Reserve 1-2 weeks ahead; takes place in a professional teaching kitchen

cooking_classes.name: Bacalao al Pil Pil Masterclass
what_you_learn: Creating the Perfect Pil Pil Sauce Emulsion
includes: All ingredients, recipe booklet, full meal with wine pairings
cooking_classes.booking_tips: Book at least 10 days in advance; focuses on the iconic Basque cod preparation

cooking_classes.name: Basque Desserts & Pastries Class
includes: All materials, recipes, dessert sampling with coffee and digestifs
cooking_classes.booking_tips: Book 1 week ahead; suitable for all skill levels

markets.name: Mercado de la Ribera
highlights: Fresh seafood, produce, meats, and cheeses
Pintxo bars and restaurants on ground floor
markets.hours: Monday to Friday 8:00 AM - 2:30 PM and 5:00 PM - 7:00 PM, Saturday 8:00 AM - 3:00 PM
markets.local_tips: The fish section is particularly impressive; ground floor restaurants serve the same fresh products found upstairs

markets.name: Mercado del Ensanche
highlights: Upscale indoor market with premium products
markets.hours: Monday to Friday 9:00 AM - 8:00 PM, Saturday 9:00 AM - 3:00 PM
markets.local_tips: More upscale than La Ribera with specialty and imported products; good place to find souvenirs like premium olive oils and wines

markets.name: Sunday Rastro Market
markets.local_tips: Beyond food, offers antiques and collectibles; surrounded by pintxo bars for post-shopping refreshment

winter: Bacalao al Pil Pil (Salt Cod with Garlic Sauce)
Txipirones en su Tinta (Squid in Ink Sauce)

destinations.whyGo: Experience this elegant coastal city with its spectacular beaches, world-renowned pintxo culture, and beautiful Belle Époque architecture.
Discover the capital of Cantabria with its beautiful bay, historic buildings, and El Sardinero beach promenade.
Visit the capital of the Basque Country with its well-preserved medieval old town, Gothic cathedral, and commitment to sustainability.
Explore this historic Basque town, immortalized by Picasso's famous painting and significant to Basque history and identity.
Experience the capital of Navarre, known for the Running of the Bulls festival, medieval city walls, and excellent pintxo bars.
Discover the capital of La Rioja wine region with its tapas-lined Calle Laurel, historic center, and excellent wine culture.
Explore this historic city with its magnificent Gothic cathedral, Camino de Santiago connections, and excellent regional cuisine.
Visit this charming fishing village with its beautiful beach, island that can be walked to at low tide, and authentic Basque atmosphere.
Experience this historic Castilian city with its impressive Gothic cathedral, Roman walls, and position on the Camino de Santiago.
Discover this underrated city with its magnificent Moorish palace, impressive basilica, and blend of Islamic, Gothic and Renaissance architecture.
Explore Spain's vibrant capital with its world-class museums, grand boulevards, beautiful parks, and energetic nightlife.
Visit Catalonia's vibrant capital with its distinctive Gaudí architecture, Mediterranean beaches, and renowned cuisine.
Experience Spain's third-largest city with its futuristic City of Arts and Sciences, historic old town, and beautiful beaches.
Discover Andalusia's capital with its blend of Moorish architecture, flamenco traditions, and vibrant street life.
Experience the iconic City of Light with its world-famous landmarks, unparalleled museums, and legendary culinary scene.
Visit this elegant port city known for its wine heritage, 18th-century architecture, and vibrant culinary scene.
Experience the 'Pink City' with its distinctive brick architecture, aerospace industry, and vibrant southern French culture.
Explore one of the world's most dynamic cities with its historic landmarks, cultural diversity, and cutting-edge arts scene.
Discover Portugal's captivating capital with its historic trams, Fado music, and beautiful hillside setting on the Tagus River.
Visit Portugal's second city known for its port wine cellars, medieval riverside district, and stunning bridge architecture.
Discover the Eternal City with its ancient ruins, Renaissance masterpieces, and vibrant street life.
Explore the EU capital with its magnificent Grand Place, Art Nouveau architecture, and renowned chocolate and beer.
Discover Germany's dynamic capital with its turbulent history, cutting-edge arts scene, and legendary nightlife.
Experience the Netherlands' vibrant capital with its iconic canals, world-class museums, and distinctive architecture.
Visit this picturesque fishing port with its colorful harbor, historic old town, and access to the stunning San Juan de Gaztelugatxe.
Explore this beautiful coastal town with its medieval church, fishing port, and beaches just east of Bilbao.
Experience this charming coastal village known for its grilled fish, Balenciaga Museum, and excellent txakoli white wine.
Visit this dramatic islet connected to the mainland by a man-made bridge, crowned by a hermitage and featured in Game of Thrones.
Discover this surfing hotspot known for having one of Europe's best left-hand waves, set within the beautiful Urdaibai Biosphere Reserve.
Explore this UNESCO-protected natural area with its diverse ecosystems including marshes, beaches, forests, and important bird habitats.
Visit this beautiful fortified border town with its colorful fishermen's houses, excellent pintxo bars, and beach alongside the French border.
Experience Spain's most famous wine region with its picturesque vineyards, historic bodegas, and charming wine towns.
Discover this historic town with its impressive university, Baroque church, and proximity to the spectacular Aizkorri-Aratz Natural Park.
Explore one of Spain's most impressive mountain ranges with dramatic limestone peaks, deep gorges, and traditional villages.

activities.name: Flores en la Ría Festival
activities.description: Experience Bilbao in bloom during this spring celebration featuring floral installations, garden exhibitions, and landscaping displays along the Nervión River.
activities.seasonal_notes: Late March through April transforms Bilbao's riverfront walkways and bridges with spectacular floral displays celebrating spring's arrival.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required; self-guided walking maps available at tourist information centers. Weekday visits offer a more relaxed experience.

activities.name: Basque Derby: Athletic Club vs. Real Sociedad
activities.description: Experience the passion of Basque football at San Mamés Stadium during this historic rivalry between Bilbao's Athletic Club and San Sebastian's Real Sociedad.
activities.seasonal_notes: Spring fixtures in La Liga season (typically March-May) offer more pleasant weather for match attendance than winter games.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase tickets through Athletic Club's official website well in advance; matches often sell out. International ID required for ticket collection.

activities.name: Semana Santa (Holy Week) Processions
activities.description: Witness Bilbao's traditional Easter processions featuring religious brotherhoods carrying elaborate floats through the Old Town and city center.
activities.seasonal_notes: Dates vary each year (March-April) with processions throughout Holy Week, particularly impressive on Holy Thursday and Good Friday.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required; arrive early to secure viewing spots along the main procession routes in Casco Viejo and Gran Vía.

activities.name: Mount Artxanda Bloom
activities.description: Take the historic funicular railway to Mount Artxanda to experience panoramic views of Bilbao surrounded by spring blossoms and greenery.
activities.seasonal_notes: April and May offer lush green landscapes and clear days with optimal visibility of the surrounding mountains and cityscape.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required for the funicular, which runs every 15 minutes. Visit on weekdays to avoid weekend crowds; bring a picnic to enjoy at the summit.

activities.name: Basque Spring Cuisine Tour
activities.description: Discover seasonal Basque delicacies featuring spring ingredients like white asparagus, anchovies, and spring lamb through restaurant special menus.
activities.seasonal_notes: April through June showcases the finest spring produce in Basque cuisine, with many restaurants offering special seasonal tasting menus.
activities.booking_tips: Reserve tables at acclaimed restaurants like Mina or Zarate to experience their spring menus. Lunch reservations are easier to secure than dinner.

activities.name: Bilbao BBK Running Festival
activities.description: Join or watch this popular running event with various race distances through Bilbao's most scenic neighborhoods and iconic landmarks.
activities.price_range: Budget to participate, Free to watch
activities.seasonal_notes: Typically held in May, the event offers comfortable spring temperatures ideal for running across Bilbao's distinctive city landscape.
activities.booking_tips: Register online months in advance to participate in races. Spectators can watch for free along the route, with prime viewing spots near the Guggenheim and City Hall.

activities.name: Txakoli Wine Season
activities.description: Experience the release of new vintage Txakoli, the Basque Country's distinctive slightly sparkling white wine, with special tastings and pairings.
activities.seasonal_notes: Spring marks the release of new Txakoli vintages, celebrated throughout Bilbao's wine bars and surrounding wine-producing areas like Getaria.
activities.booking_tips: Reserve spots for guided Txakoli tastings through Bilbao tourism office or join a day trip to nearby Txakoli producers in Getaria or Bakio.

activities.name: Bilbao Architecture Week
activities.description: Explore Bilbao's renowned architectural heritage through special tours, exhibitions, and open buildings during this annual celebration.
activities.seasonal_notes: Held in May, this event celebrates Bilbao's transformation through architecture with unique access to significant buildings and special exhibitions.
activities.booking_tips: Check the official website for program details; popular tours of iconic buildings like the Guggenheim behind-the-scenes should be booked well in advance.

activities.name: Day Trip to Urdaibai Biosphere Reserve
activities.description: Explore this UNESCO-protected coastal ecosystem during spring migration season when thousands of birds pass through its marshes and forests.
activities.seasonal_notes: April and May are ideal for birdwatching as migratory species pass through, while spring flora transforms the landscape with vibrant colors.
activities.booking_tips: Take the direct train from Bilbao-Atxuri station to Busturia-Itsasbegi for the Urdaibai Bird Center. Guided tours should be booked online in advance.

activities.name: Aste Nagusia (Great Week) Festival
activities.description: Experience Bilbao's largest festival featuring nine days of concerts, traditional sports, street performances, fireworks, and bullfights throughout the city.
activities.seasonal_notes: Held in late August, this massive celebration brings the entire city to life with festivities led by the symbolic figure Marijaia.
activities.booking_tips: No booking needed for most events; accommodation should be reserved months in advance as the city fills completely during this period.

activities.name: Bilbao BBK Live Music Festival
activities.description: Attend one of Spain's premier music festivals featuring international headliners across multiple stages on Mount Cobetas overlooking the city.
activities.seasonal_notes: Held in early July, this three-day festival combines world-class music with stunning hillside views of Bilbao and camping options.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase tickets months in advance; festival and camping passes sell out quickly. Shuttle buses run from central Bilbao to the venue.

activities.name: Beaches of Getxo and Sopelana
activities.description: Escape the city heat at nearby coastal beaches accessible by metro, offering swimming, sunbathing, and renowned surfing conditions.
activities.seasonal_notes: June through September offers warm temperatures ideal for beach activities, with August being the busiest month as locals vacation.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required; take Metro Line 1 to Algorta or Sopelana. Visit on weekdays to avoid weekend crowds.

activities.name: Kayaking on the Nervión River
activities.description: Paddle through the heart of Bilbao on guided kayak tours offering unique perspectives of the city's iconic architecture from the water.
activities.seasonal_notes: Summer provides calm water conditions and warm temperatures ideal for exploring Bilbao's rejuvenated riverfront by water.
activities.booking_tips: Book tours through Bilboats or similar operators at least several days in advance, especially for weekend slots.

activities.name: Open-Air Cinema at Abandoibarra
activities.description: Enjoy films under the stars with the illuminated Guggenheim and Nervión River as backdrop at this summer cinema series.
activities.seasonal_notes: Screenings run through July and August, with films beginning after sunset around 10:00 PM in typical Spanish fashion.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase tickets online or arrive early; bring something to sit on and light layers as evenings can cool down even in summer.

activities.name: Getxo International Jazz Festival
activities.description: Experience world-class jazz performances in the seaside district of Getxo, combining music with beautiful coastal scenery just outside Bilbao.
activities.seasonal_notes: Held in early July, this prestigious festival features performances in both indoor venues and outdoor stages near the historic port.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase tickets online in advance; easily accessible from Bilbao via metro to Algorta station.

activities.name: Basque Coast Hiking Tour
activities.description: Hike sections of the dramatic coastal path between Bilbao and San Sebastian, featuring stunning cliffs, fishing villages, and beaches.
activities.seasonal_notes: Summer offers the most reliable weather for coastal hiking, though early morning starts are recommended to avoid midday heat.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required for self-guided hiking; public transportation connects various sections of the trail. The Uribe Kosta route from Plentzia to Sopelana is particularly accessible from Bilbao.

activities.name: San Mamés Stadium Tour
activities.description: Visit Athletic Club's legendary stadium, known as 'The Cathedral of Football,' through guided tours explaining the club's unique Basque-only player policy and history.
activities.seasonal_notes: Summer offers the chance to visit when no matches are scheduled, providing full access to areas normally restricted during the season.
activities.booking_tips: Book tours online through Athletic Club's official website; English-language tours available on specific days.

activities.name: Vizcaya Bridge Experience
activities.description: Visit the world's oldest transporter bridge, a UNESCO site connecting Portugalete and Getxo, with the option to ride the gondola or walk across the high panoramic walkway.
activities.seasonal_notes: Summer provides clear views from the upper walkway, with pleasant temperatures for enjoying the coastal areas on either side of the bridge.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required; regular gondola crossings operate throughout the day. The upper walkway requires a separate ticket and may close in windy conditions.

activities.name: BIME Live Music Festival and Conference
activities.description: Experience this dual music festival and industry conference featuring cutting-edge artists and music business innovators at the BEC venue.
activities.best_time: Evening for concerts, Day for conference
activities.seasonal_notes: Held in late October/early November, this event brings international music industry focus to Bilbao with both public concerts and professional conferences.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase festival tickets online well in advance; industry conference passes available separately for music professionals.

activities.name: Rioja Alavesa Wine Harvest
activities.description: Experience the autumn grape harvest in the nearby Rioja Alavesa wine region with special winery tours, tastings, and harvest festivals.
activities.seasonal_notes: September and October mark the grape harvest season, when wineries come alive with activity and the countryside displays autumn colors.
activities.booking_tips: Book guided tours from Bilbao with transportation included, or rent a car to explore independently. Major wineries like Ysios and Marqués de Riscal require advance reservations.

activities.name: Bilbao Mushroom Foraging
activities.description: Join guided mushroom hunting excursions in the forests surrounding Bilbao during peak season for this important Basque culinary tradition.
activities.seasonal_notes: October and November offer ideal conditions for mushroom growth after autumn rains, with expert guides helping identify edible varieties.
activities.booking_tips: Book through specialized tour operators like Bilbao Food Safari or local mycological associations; tours fill quickly during peak mushroom season.

activities.name: International Documentary Film Festival (Zinebi)
activities.description: Attend this prestigious documentary and short film festival featuring screenings, director talks, and workshops throughout Bilbao.
activities.seasonal_notes: Held in November, this festival brings international documentary filmmakers to Bilbao during the atmospheric autumn season.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase tickets online once the program is released; festival passes offer the best value for multiple screenings.

activities.name: Pintxo Championship Season
activities.description: Sample award-winning and competition pintxos as Bilbao's best bars compete in various autumn championships, creating innovative special offerings.
activities.seasonal_notes: Various pintxo competitions run through autumn, inspiring bars to create their most creative and delicious offerings to win prestigious titles.
activities.booking_tips: No reservations needed for most pintxo bars; follow local food blogs or tourist office announcements to track which bars are competing and what their special competition pintxos are.

activities.name: Guggenheim Autumn Exhibition
activities.description: Experience the Guggenheim's major autumn exhibition, typically featuring international contemporary artists in specially curated shows.
activities.seasonal_notes: Autumn brings significant new exhibitions after the summer tourist season, often presenting the museum's most ambitious curatorial projects.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase timed-entry tickets online to avoid queues; visit on weekday mornings for a more contemplative experience.

activities.name: Txotx Cider Season Opening
activities.description: Experience the beginning of Basque cider season with special events at sagardotegis (cider houses) featuring traditional cider-pouring rituals.
activities.seasonal_notes: The cider season traditionally begins in late autumn, when new cider starts to mature and sagardotegis prepare for the official January opening.
activities.booking_tips: Reserve spots for special pre-season events through local cider houses or join organized tours from Bilbao to nearby cider-producing regions.

activities.name: El Arenal Market Autumn Harvest
activities.description: Explore Bilbao's historic market as it showcases autumn's bounty including wild mushrooms, game meats, and seasonal produce from the Basque countryside.
activities.seasonal_notes: October through December brings the richest seasonal products to the market, with specialized vendors offering foraged and hunted autumn delicacies.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required; visit early on weekday mornings for the freshest selection and to watch locals selecting seasonal specialties.

activities.name: Basque Mountain Hiking
activities.description: Experience the spectacular autumn colors in the mountains surrounding Bilbao, with hiking routes for all levels featuring dramatic landscapes.
activities.seasonal_notes: October provides ideal hiking conditions with comfortable temperatures, clear visibility, and forests transformed with fall colors.
activities.booking_tips: Join guided hikes through mountain clubs or tourist operators for the best experience; popular routes include Gorbea Natural Park and Urkiola Natural Park.

activities.name: Santo Tomás Festival
activities.description: Experience Bilbao's traditional pre-Christmas market featuring Basque rural products, traditional txistorra sausage, and cultural demonstrations.
activities.seasonal_notes: Held on December 21st, this festival transforms Plaza Nueva and the Old Town into a celebration of Basque rural traditions and winter foods.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required; arrive early to avoid the largest crowds. Bring cash for food purchases from traditional farmhouse stalls.

activities.name: Txotx Cider Season
activities.description: Participate in the traditional Basque cider house experience, where new season's cider is poured directly from large barrels accompanied by a special menu.
activities.seasonal_notes: The official season begins mid-January and runs through spring, with special opening ceremonies at major cider houses in the region.
activities.booking_tips: Reserve well in advance for popular sagardotegis (cider houses); organized tours from Bilbao with transportation simplify the experience.

activities.name: Bilbao Arte Contemporary Art Winter Program
activities.description: Explore cutting-edge exhibitions by emerging artists at this dynamic art center housed in a converted warehouse in Bilbao's creative district.
activities.seasonal_notes: Winter features thought-provoking exhibitions by artists-in-residence and the winter program typically offers the most experimental work.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required; check their website for special events, artist talks, and workshop opportunities during exhibitions.

activities.name: Skiing Day Trip to Formigal
activities.description: Take a day trip to the nearby Pyrenees for skiing and snowboarding at one of Spain's premier winter resorts, accessible from Bilbao.
activities.seasonal_notes: December through March offers reliable snow conditions, with January and February typically providing the best skiing weather.
activities.booking_tips: Book organized day trips including transportation and lift tickets, or rent a car for more flexibility. Equipment rental available at the resort.

activities.name: Three Kings Parade (Cabalgata de Reyes)
activities.description: Experience Spain's most important Christmas tradition as the Three Kings parade through Bilbao distributing candies and bringing gifts to children.
activities.seasonal_notes: Held on January 5th, the eve of Epiphany, this spectacular parade features elaborate floats and costumes across central Bilbao.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required; arrive early for good viewing spots along Gran Vía and bring bags for children to collect thrown candies.

activities.name: Bilbao Winter Gastronomy
activities.description: Experience traditional Basque winter cuisine featuring hearty stews, bean dishes, and salt cod preparations at Bilbao's finest restaurants.
activities.seasonal_notes: January and February feature specialized winter menus highlighting warming dishes like alubias de Tolosa (black bean stew) and bacalao al pil-pil (cod in garlic sauce).
activities.booking_tips: Reserve traditional restaurants like Restaurante Askora or Bascook to experience authentic winter Basque cuisine at its best. Lunch reservations are generally easier to secure than dinner.

activities.name: Athletic Club Football Match
activities.description: Experience the passion of Basque football at San Mamés Stadium, known as 'The Cathedral,' during the heart of La Liga season.
activities.seasonal_notes: Winter matches (December-February) often feature the most important fixtures of the season in comfortable conditions inside the state-of-the-art stadium.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase tickets through Athletic Club's official website weeks in advance; international ID required for ticket collection. The atmosphere for derby matches against Real Sociedad or local rivals is particularly special.

activities.name: Carnival (Carnaval) in Bilbao
activities.description: Experience Bilbao's version of carnival featuring costumes, parades, music, and the ceremonial burning of the carnival figure 'El Momo'.
activities.seasonal_notes: Held in February or early March (date varies by liturgical calendar), bringing color and festivities to the city during the winter season.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required for public celebrations; check the city's cultural agenda for specific events and parade routes.

activities.name: FIG Bilbao - International Printmaking Festival
activities.description: Explore this unique art fair dedicated to fine art printmaking, featuring galleries, master printers, and artists from around the world.
activities.seasonal_notes: Typically held in November/December, this specialized art event showcases the rich tradition of printmaking in an intimate setting.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase tickets online or at the venue; check the program for demonstrations, workshops, and artist talks that require separate registration.

ranges.notes: New Year's Day (Jan 1) is a public holiday. Three Kings celebration (Jan 5-6) features a spectacular parade and gift-giving tradition. January 6 is a public holiday.
Traditional opening of cider season in nearby cider houses (sagardotegis) with special menus and cider-pouring rituals
Winter sales begin, fewer tourists, cold but typically milder than northern Europe, excellent time for museum visits like the Guggenheim and Fine Arts Museum
Low season with fewer tourists, good value accommodations, perfect for museum visits and pintxo crawls without crowds
Special menus at restaurants, romantic dining opportunities with views of the illuminated Guggenheim
Colorful celebration with parades, costumes, and festivities throughout the city, especially in the Old Town (Casco Viejo)
Early spring with improving weather, almond blossoms in surrounding countryside, fewer tourists than high season

ranges.event: Semana Santa (Holy Week - varies by year)
ranges.notes: Major religious festival with processions through the Old Town, traditional music, and special cultural events
If Easter falls in April, Holy Week processions continue with major events on Holy Thursday and Good Friday
Spring weather establishes, ideal for exploring both city and countryside, excellent time for Basque coastal towns and spring cuisine
Public holiday with demonstrations and events throughout the city
Special tours and events highlighting Bilbao's architectural renaissance, including behind-the-scenes access to notable buildings
Early summer with excellent weather, perfect for combining city exploration with nearby beaches like Sopelana and Plentzia
Midsummer celebration with bonfires on nearby beaches, traditional dances, and festivities on June 23-24
Major international music festival held on Mount Cobetas overlooking the city, featuring global music stars and camping options
Peak summer season with warm temperatures, good time for exploring Bilbao's riverfront and taking day trips to coastal towns
Peak tourist season with many locals on vacation, some businesses may close, excellent beach weather
Bilbao's massive nine-day festival with concerts, traditional sports, fireworks, bullfights, and street performances throughout the city
The Great Week festival may continue into early September depending on the calendar
Excellent weather continues with fewer tourists than August, perfect time to explore the city and nearby wine regions
Comfortable autumn temperatures, fall colors in surrounding mountains, excellent for hiking and cultural activities
National holiday with events and celebrations throughout the city
Contemporary music festival and industry conference featuring international artists at the BEC venue
Public holiday with traditional cemetery visits and special services
Quieter tourism period, cooler weather, excellent for museum visits and gastronomic experiences
Prestigious film festival showcasing documentaries and short films at venues throughout the city
Public holidays on December 6 (Constitution) and December 8 (Immaculate Conception) with special events
Christmas markets and decorations throughout the city, festive atmosphere at Plaza Nueva and Gran Vía
Traditional Basque market celebrating rural traditions with txistorra sausage, artisanal products, and cultural displays
Shopping period before Christmas, traditional Olentzero (Basque Santa) appearances
Public holiday with limited opening hours, family-focused celebration
Post-Christmas period with continued holiday atmosphere, winter sales begin
Celebrations throughout the city, particularly in Plaza Nueva and around the Guggenheim, with the tradition of eating 12 grapes at midnight

spring: Mount Artxanda Funicular Rides for City Views
Flores en la Ría Festival Along the Riverside
Semana Santa Processions in Casco Viejo
Athletic Club Football Matches at San Mamés
Day Trips to Urdaibai Biosphere Reserve
Spring Lamb Dishes at Traditional Restaurants
summer: Beaches at Getxo, Sopelana, and Plentzia
Rooftop Dining with Views of the Guggenheim
autumn: Mushroom Foraging Day Trips with Guides
Autumn Colors in Gorbea Natural Park
Chestnut and Cider Season Gastronomic Events
winter: Three Kings Parade in City Center
Santo Tomás Market at Plaza Nueva
Day Trips to Nearby Ski Resorts
New Year's Eve Celebrations in Plaza Nueva

scoreDescription.1: Poor: Unfavorable conditions, extreme weather, overcrowded or very limited activities
scoreDescription.2: Below Average: Less ideal conditions, possibly unpleasant weather or very low/high tourism (business closures)
scoreDescription.3: Average: Standard conditions, typical weather, moderate to high tourism
scoreDescription.4: Good: Very favorable conditions, pleasant weather, manageable crowds
scoreDescription.5: Excellent: Perfect conditions, special events, ideal weather, moderate crowds
